subject: How to handle "er" and "ur" in QS
msgSnippet: The vowel in bird or word has not good representation in QS. The IPA maps it to /ɜ/, or the open-mid central unrounded vowel, at least for American
messageBody:
The vowel in "bird" or "word" has not good representation in QS. The IPA
maps it to /ɜ/, or the open-mid central unrounded vowel, at least for
American English. The manual simply suggests using "Ado" "Roar" for the
"ir" sound in such words. For the most part, this works well. I found
when I first tried to read "Ado" "Roar" I would try to pronounce an
"Ado" sound, which wouldn't get me very far. Now in most cases I can see
the combination and read the two sounds together.

However, in some cases, this combination becomes confusing. Consider the
word arena, spelled

Ado Roar Eat Nun Ado

The first two letters immediately make me think I need to pronounce the
"ir" as in "bird." At this point it takes me a while to decipher the
word, to realize that in this case the "Ado" stands on its on. Perhaps
this problem is just due to my inexperience. I might have had the same
problem when first learning to read English, trying to figure out how to
break the syllables.

On the other hand, I wonder if we shouldn't agree on a convention of
using the ligatures for the "ir" sound (the majority of cases), and
using the separate letters for the others. Though this suggestion may go
somewhat against Read's intention, he himself didn't really provide a
good way to express the "ir" in bird. You really don't use an "Ado"
vowel here.

Paul
